DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says Noriega Drove in Circles After Invasion
Eds: ADDS one graf on U.S. report other Noriega associates also went to the embassy that day
With AM-Panama, AM-Panama-Military
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega probably went by himself to the Vatican Embassy and decided to seek asylum after his aides abandoned him or were arrested, the U.S. Southern Command said Tuesday. It said Noriega was never in charge of his Defense Forces after the U.S. invasion on Dec. 20 and did not contact any of its members for fear of a trap. During the fighting, military spokesmen had said the resistance was centrally directed and Noriega was involved. In a brief communique released to reporters, Southern Command gave an account of Noriega's time after the invasion based on what it said were interviews with his cronies. Noriega at one point considered ``fleeing to the mountains to mount an insurgent attack, but he was concerned about his heart while living in difficult terrain without the opulent luxuries and intensive medical care'' to which he had become accustomed, according to the communique. It quoted aides who were interviewed as saying Noriega wore red underwear to ward off the ``evil eye.'' The communique said that before the invasion, Noriega had dismissed the possibility of an attack by U.S. troops and was in Colon, 50 miles north of Panama City, inspecting a new military facility. ``He was aware of increased U.S. force activities but discounted the notion of an attack, passing the increased activity off as more U.S. posturing,'' the communique said. It said that about 6 p.m. on Dec. 19, he was dropped off at a Panamanian Defense Forces club in Tocumen near the Omar Torrijos airport. ``There he was provided a prostitute by one of his aides _ apparently a routine occurrence,'' it said. When Tocumen was attacked about 1 a.m., Noriega left the club and evaded U.S. forces by driving around Panama City, according to the communique. Southern Command said Noriega's first telephone call after the invasion was to his mistress, Vicky Amado, and that he never tried to contact his wife, Felicidad. It said Noriega was ``agitated'' and spent the days at various locations, mostly at the home of relatives of his private secretary, Marcella Tason. His supporters tried to make him leave town but he refused, it said. It added that at one point, Noriega was believed to have contacted the Cuban ambassador and considered going to Cuba's embassy but backed off because the compound was surrounded by U.S. troops. The Bush administration had set a $1 million bounty for Noriega. Southern Command said Noriega decided to go ``single-handed'' to the Vatican Embassy after one of his commanders, Luis del Cid, surrendered to U.S. forces in David, 200 miles west of Panama City. Del Cid was indicted in 1988 along with Noriega on drug trafficking charges. He was flown to Miami Monday. Other people were seen entering the Vatican Embassy at various times on the same day Noriega went there. Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said Tuesday in Washington that ``10 associate thugs'' of Noriega sought asylum Sunday afternoon at the embassy, the Papal Nunciature.
